changes_made: Treatment of uncomplicated Hep C patients
Trying to recruit HCV patients at my clinic for treatment.

I have learned about more up to date treatment regimes that will help with my treatment of Hepatitis C.  I have learned the necessary screenings that I was not previous aware of needed for Hepatitis C patients.  I truly feel that I am better able to educate both my patients and my co-workers about Hepatitis C and its treatment.
I now have a flow from diagnosis to evaluation for treatment.

The first round through the ECHO Hep C Series gave me baseline knowledge to begin to think about treating patients with Hep C myself; I have improved my skills to ready patients for treatment including having a better understanding of staging
Prior auth forms and routing improved, have an inhouse weekly discussion of what we learned in ECHO and how that applies to our pt s
feeling more confident in stratifying Hep C patients who should be treated.
I am now treating several patients for Hep C and this is something I never would have done in the past.
a better treater
working with a few uninsured patients to try to obtain hep c meds through industry and not refer to subspecialists
My HepC screening practices have changed; in addition to screening based on risk factors, I screen an age-based cohort (born 1945-1965).
Increased amount of patients treated for Hep C with new knowledge of accessing health care system/insurance
Educating patients with Hepatitis C that treatment is available with rare side effects & ordering necessary tests for staging of disease & ordering labs necessary for medication approval.

Created a Hep C clinic  Able to relay the PA process through a Specialty pharmacy  Refer patients to FibroScan rather than a Liver biopsy  Use of APRI  In Diabetic patients with Cirrhosis, pay attention to Lactic Acidosis
I know which tests to order and what results mean and what next steps are
